marc:datafield.marc:subfield: John Graham served as lieutenant governor of Georgia from 1779 to 1782.
List of accounts of John Graham with John Sommerville in Savannah, 1773, and a letter concerning the sale of horses, 1776. Graham later served as lieutenant governor of Georgia, 1779-1782.
Scattered papers of New Bern, N.C. merchant James Green.
Richard L. Green was apparently the manager or administrator of the New Bank Estate (location unidentified).
Collection consists of lists of wages paid to white and African-American laborers. Items noted include drayage, wheelbarrows, and sawyers.
Edwin Gray (1743-1813?) was a Republican member of the U.S. House of Representatives for Virginia from 1799 to 1813.

Letter from Edwin Gray in which he objects strongly to a printed notice (Jan. 13, 1808) sent out by Senator Stephen Row Bradley calling for a meeting on Jan. 23, 1808 of the Republican members of both houses of Congress for the purpose of nominating "suitable and proper characters for President and Vice President of the United States for the next presidential election." Gray called the proposed meeting a "midnight intrigue" against the sacred right of the American people to select persons to fill these offices. Senator Bradley's notice is enclosed with the letter.

Morning reports and forage and provision returns of Captain A. Stevenson's company of artillery of 2nd Elite Corps of the Virginia militia commanded by Col. Moses Green, in the service of the U.S. Army; and regimental orders issued by Green. Reports and returns were issued from Camp Holly near New Market, Virginia and Camp Charles City Court House, Virginia.
Charles Gratiot was Chief Engineer of the Army Corps of Engineers from 1828 to 1838.
Letters to engineers at Fortress Monroe and Old Point Comfort, Va. relative to the construction of lighters, the supplying of construction materials for fortifications, and other matters.
Richard Gregory was presumably a resident of Virginia and married to Elizabeth Gregory.
Papers concern the administration of the estate of Elizabeth Gregory.

Correspondence between Graham, of Salisbury (Rowan Co.), N.C., and a brother-in-law, Joseph W. Rogers of Cabarrus County, largely concerning their family; mention is made of the execution of a slave for murder. A letter from John W.B. Houston, nephew of Graham, from Fort Washataw, Ark., 1847, concerns the Mexican War and the economic opportunities in Arkansas; one from Marshall, Tex., 1850, relates to slave trading and praises the Chickasaw Indians with whom he is doing business.
William J. Grayson was a congressman from South Carolina.

Collection includes a letter from Grayson while in Congress, to his son William John, Jr. in school in Charleston, which is completely personal and gives fatherly advice to the young student about his social life. Also includes a "Commission in Equity for the District of Beaufort," granted to Grayson in 1832 by the governor of S.C., James Hamilton, Jr.
Col. William Graves was a resident of Bedford (formerly Liberty) County, Virginia.
Horatio Greenough was a sculptor born in Boston, Mass. He graduated from Harvard (1825) and settled in Florence, Italy in 1828. He sculpted George Washington in 1840.
Collection consists of a contemporary copy of a letter from Greenough to George W. Green mentioning fellow sculptors Shobal Vail Clevenger and Thomas Crawford.
Lawyer, banker, educator, and Congressman, from Canandaigua (Ontario Co.), N.Y.

Principally the letters of Robert Wilson, a Liverpool merchant, discussing the grain trade, the Anglo-American dispute over Oregon, the Mexican War, and politics in England, mentioning Lord John Russell, Sir Robert Peel, and the repeal of the Corn Laws.

John Breckinridge Grayson was born in Kentucky and graduated from West Point in 1826. He was an officer in the U.S. Army, served in the Mexican War, and, briefly, as a Confederate brigadier general during the Civil War.
Collection consists largely of checks and receipts for money paid out for supplies during the Mexican War. A letter, 1853, concerns the purchase of a farm in Virginia.
D. W. Gray was a Texas Ranger.

Letter, dated 1849 April 18, from D. W. Gray of the Texas Rangers at Monterrey, Mexico where the Rangers were fighting the Comanche in the northeastern states of Mexico. Gray had resigned his commission as a lieutenant with the Virginia Regiment, and joined the Texas Rangers.
W. B. Green probably resided in Petersburg, Va.

Collection consists of two letters referring to legal matters and particularly whether Green would have to go to Tennessee for making a deposition. The letters are addressed to the law firm of Smith and Herndon in Eutaw, Alabama.
James S. Gray was a Virginian living in Washington, D.C.

Collection consists largely of family and political papers of James S. Gray, a Virginian living in Washington, D.C. Political letters, mostly from Richmond, Va., contain a few by J. Ambler Smith commenting on Tilden and Hayes in the 1870s. A letter from 1881 comments on purchase rates of Confederate bonds by brokers.
Barry Gray was also known as Robert Barry Coffin and was editor of "Home Journal" and "The Table."
Collection consists of a letter from author Frederick Swartwout Cozzens to Robert Barry Coffin acknowledging receipt of a check, and declining an invitation.

Included are a letter from Gen. William J. Hardee to Gen. Sherman asking the protection of Mrs. Gray, a Northerner, during the Union occupation; a reply by Sherman; and an order that the Gray family not be molested.
Primarily personal letters written to Graham by her cousins, one of whom is a Presbyterian minister.

Collection consists of letters to C.H. Green from relatives who went to Hannibal, Missouri before the Civil War. The first letter describes a fire in Hannibal. Other letters express grave concern over the outbreak of war.
George H. Gray was a conservative Whig of West Cambridge, Mass.

Letter (1861 Jan. 2) from George H. Gray to Rev. Samuel Abbot Smith during the Secession Crisis, for which he blames the Massachusetts clergy and the failure of the state to follow the advice of Daniel Webster. Gray also mentioned the Fugitive Slave Law, the necessity of extending slavery into the territories to prevent war, and his difficulty with Dr. Convers Francis.
W. T. Green was a private in the Confederate Army, probably in a Georgia regiment. In 1862 he was stationed at Yorktown, Virginia.
Collection consists of letters from W. T. Green to his aunt and uncle, mostly regarding his cousin, Henry, who he served with in his regiment and died of typhoid fever on March 7, 1862.
David Greene was a Confederate soldier.

Collection consists of three personal letters of David Greene. Two letters from Greene discuss health conditions in the Confederate Army and casualties on both sides in the Battle of Dranesville, Virginia (1861). A third letter is from Green's sister Ginnie and concerns matters back at home.
Alfred Burton Greenwood of Arkansas was a lawyer, congressman, and U.S. Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Collection consists of a letter from Greenwood, a Unionist, to John T. Cochran expressing concern over secession and the mortgage and insurance on property he owns in Washington, D.C. He asks Cochran to handle some matters related to the property and notes that he has advised the Indians on the border of Arkansas to remain neutral, at least for the present.
Maxcy Gregg was a Confederate soldier who was killed in the Battle of Fredericksburg on December 14, 1862.
Collection contains a letter from Captain J. M. Gladberry of the 1st Regiment of South Carolina to Gregg requesting more arms and ammunition for his company.
William L. Gregg was a soldier in the Confederate Army.

Two letters between Confederate soldiers commenting on camp life and noting the strong religious feelings which characterized one type of soldier. The letters are written from South Island, S.C. and Camp Huger, Virginia.
Adolphus Washington Greely (1844-1935) was a soldier, explorer, scientist, and author born in Newburyport, Massachusetts.

Collection consists mainly of letters sent from Greely to his brother, John Augustus Greely, and to his likely brother-in-law, John W. Winder. The letters date from three periods: 1863-1866, 1888-1890, and 1903-1909. The earliest letters pertain to Greely's obtaining a position in a regiment of the 81st U.S. Colored Infantry, which participated in the Seige of Port Hudson, Louisiana and was transferred to New Orleans following the Civil War. Greely describes the political events leading up to the New Orleans Massacre (New Orleans Race Riot) of 1866, his unit's role in the conflict, and the impact that the conflict had on his career trajectory. Letters from later periods are more routine, mostly discussing visits to Newburyport as well as financial and legal matters. There are a few letters related to his duties in San Francisco in 1906.
William Gregg was the founder of the Graniteville Company and a pioneer cotton manufacturer in S.C.
Letter from James B. Campbell to Gregg concerning legal affairs.
Typescript copy of the diary kept by a sergeant in the 53rd Illinois Volunteer Infantry during the Atlanta campaign and after.
John J. Gravatt was a surgeon in the Confederate Army.

A report, November 16, 1864, by Assistant Surgeon S. P. Christian on a trip to North Carolina to entrain a group of sick and wounded soldiers, addressed to John J. Gravatt, medical officer in charge at General Hospital No. 9 in Richmond.
Protestant Episcopal minister, from Sewanee (Franklin Co.), Tenn; founder of the University of the South.

Personal correspondence of Bishop Green, the first Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Mississippi and a founder of the University of the South in Sewanee. Included is a February 23, 1883 letter from Jefferson Davis to Green.
U.S. Army officer; president of the United States.

Letters of recommendation for office seekers during Grant's presidency of the U.S.; a letter from Peter Dox, U.S. representative from Alabama, concerning a proposed Atlantic-Mississippi canal, 1872; reminiscences of a sergeant in the 5th U.S. Cavalry about serving as a member of the bodyguard for Grant and Lincoln during their meeting at Petersburg, April 3, 1865; letters concerning minor legislation; and miscellaneous materials.
Business papers of a realtor and insurance salesman.
William Benjamin Gracie was an officer in the U.S. Army, 1898-?

Four-page letter of March 14, 1916, written at Camp Eagle Pass, Texas. He discusses the weather and living conditions of the area, making brief comparisons to tours of duty in the Philippines and Boston. Fears of attacks by Francisco "Pancho" Villa and the doubtful loyalty of the Mexicans living in the area, as well as the possibility of U.S. forces having gone across the Mexican border, are mentioned. The letter was dated the day before Pershing went into Mexico in search of Pancho Villa.
Native of Charleston, S.C., who served in the Civil War, first as a member of the Washington Light Infantry, and later reenlisting in the 25th South Carolina Infantry, Hagood's Brigade.

Typescript memoir (32 pp.) of Greer's Civil War experiences, entitled "Recollections of a Private Soldier of the Army of the Confederate States." The memoir's best descriptions involving actual combat include observations at Cold Harbor, and an anecdote concerning Greer's capture of a Union cavalry officer during the siege of Petersburg. His writing also conveys a fair sense of what life in Charleston was like during and immediately before the war. Greer also discusses the hardships endured by the men taken at Ft. Fisher and confined at Elmira, N.Y., particularly those which pertain to medical and sanitary affairs. Greer notes that pneumonia, typhoid, and smallpox spread rapidly though the prison despite honest efforts of federal authorities to contain disease. The memoir was probably written after 1921. Researchers may also wish to consult the pamphlet ROLLS OF THE WASHINGTON LIGHT INFANTRY, which lists the peronnel of all three active service companies of that organization.
